markdownRemark.html:
Dev meetings

Some time ago I was invited to take part in React Native workshops as a mentor, that means I was supposed to help other developers go through tasks and answer their questions. The workshops on various topics are called DevMeetings and are run across Poland each couple of weeks. Let’s take a look at some topics we covered there:

What They’ve learned

  • Expo

It’s very convienient tool to use especially on such occasion, when you have a couple of hours to present the most important stuff regarding a topic and you don’t want to waste it for configuration. It allows to setup from zero to running app on a device in minutes.

  • Props, state

The basics of React are all about these too. Props allow to compose components by sending from parents to children:

  import { Text } from "react-native"

  const ExampleComponent = ({ text }) => (
    <Text>
      {text}
    </Text>
  )

And state gives components ability to control encapsulated data.

  • Forms and AsyncStorage

Forms are bread nad butter of every frontend developer so it makes sense to present the idiomatic way of writing them in React Native. This was the place where we used the power of state for the purpose of saving inputs on each keystroke and then push it to AsyncStorage on form submit.

  import { AsyncStorage } from 'react-native';

  await AsyncStorage.setItem('form', form);
  ...
  const form = await AsyncStorage.getItem('form');

AsyncStorage is not the perfect solution for this case, yet the API is pretty straight forward and gives a lot of functionality without much boilerplate.

  • Navigation through an app

Or how a web developer would call it routing. With React-navigation you set up routing almost as you would do it on web. Set of screens that you access via navigation to an established route.

What I’ve noticed

  • Whether you like it or not pair programming is simply an effective way of solving a couple of software development problems by:

  • boosting Distribution of knowledge. Diminish a number of bottlenecks in the organization by encourage other people to sit together and share their knowledge and work on solutions.

  • Alleviate communication bias. Real time meetings, especially when you see other people, are way more dynamic and allow you to express more with less words. Even though your wording might not be as specific as if you wrote them, you have ability of to express by gestures and intonation, which can convey emotions. Doubt, apprehension, excitement or cheer just to name a few.

  • Tights up a feedback loop. You don’t wait 2 days after you finished development to get a corrective feedback which then forces you to redesign the solution. And then you think that the worst thing here is that the new solution is simple better, if only you got it earlier…

How many things you can do when you are passionate and curious. Mr obvious strikes again, I know, but it hammered home to me during the last workshops. The task given to people are mostly far from being mundane and obvious to participants.

Also, there are many things I thought I’d known before I was asked to explain them in detail, like aforementioned difference between div and Text, or intricate details about Expo
